tit.e: Famine in the Choroku and Kansei Era
tit.cmt: There doesn't seem to be an established translation for this, but I think "The Choroku–Kansei Famine" will work.

sen.j: 長禄・寛正の飢饉（ちょうろく・かんせいのききん）は、長禄3年（1459年）から寛正2年（1461年）にかけて日本全国を襲った飢饉のこと。
sen.e: Famine in the Choroku and Kansei Era was the famine that hit across the country between 1459 and 1461.
The Choroku–Kansei Famine was a country-wide famine that struck Japan in 1459 (the third year of the Choroku era) and lasted until 1461 (the second year of the Kansei era).
sen.cmt: Adding the years according to the Japanese calendar in parentheses makes the reason why the famine has been given this name clearer, I think.

sen.j: 長禄3年は全国的な旱魃に加えて、関東地方の享徳の乱、畿内の台風などによって西日本を中心に飢饉が発生、
sen.e: In 1459, nation-wide drought, the Kyotoku war in the Kanto region and a typhoon hitting Kinai triggered famine mainly in the western part of Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1459, a nation-wide drought, the Kyotoku war in the Kanto region, and a typhoon that struck the Kinai area triggered a famine in Japan that mainly affected the western part of the country.
In 1459, a nation-wide drought, the Kyotoku war in the Kanto region, and a typhoon that struck the Kinai area triggered a famine in Japan that mainly affected the western part of the country.

sen.j: 翌年にも大雨による水害と旱魃が交互に訪れ、更に虫害と疫病も加わって飢饉が全国で拡大、畠山氏の家督争い、斯波氏の長禄合戦などによって、両氏の領国では更に事態が深刻化した。
sen.e: In the following year, a repeated cycle of flood triggered by heavy rain and drought followed by insect damage and plague led to a nation-wide famine, and the battle over succession of the family headship within the HATAKEYAMA clan as well as the battle of Choroku of the SHIBA clan made the situation worse in their territories.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The following year, a seemingly endless cycle of rain-induced floods and droughts that was followed by insect damage and plague led to a nation-wide famine; a succession battle within the HATAKEYAMA clan and the battle of Choroku that the SHIBA clan fought made the situation in their respective territories even worse.
sen.cmt: "battle over succession of the family headship" can be expressed more concisely by just saying "succession battle", I think.
sen.e: The following year, a seemingly endless cycle of rain-induced floods and droughts that was followed by insect damage and plague led to a nation-wide famine; a succession battle within the HATAKEYAMA clan and the battle of Choroku that the SHIBA clan fought made the situation in their respective territories even worse.

sen.j: 京都では1459年旧暦8月に台風が直撃し、賀茂川が氾濫して多数の家屋が流出し、数え切れないほどの死者が出たほか、
sen.e: In August 1459 (old lunar calender), when a typhoon hit Kyoto, the Kamo-gawa River flooded, swepting away many houses and killing uncountable number of people.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In August 1459 (old lunar calender), when a typhoon hit Kyoto, the Kamo-gawa River was flooded, sweeping away many houses and killing countless numbers of people.
In September (August in old lunar calendar) 1459, when a typhoon hit Kyoto, the Kamo-gawa River was flooded, sweeping away many houses and killing countless numbers of people.
sen.cmt: lunar 削除"August 1459 (old calender)" -> "September (August in old lunar calendar) 1459" に変更しました。

sen.j: 飢饉がより深刻化した1461年（寛正2年）には、大量の流民が市中に流れ込み更に事態は悪化した。
sen.e: In 1461, with severer famine, many refugees fled to the city, making the situation even worse.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1461, struggling with severe famine, many refugees fled to the city, which only worsened the situation.
In 1461, struggling with severe famine, many refugees fled to the city, which only worsened the situation.

sen.j: 飢餓と疫病によって、寛正2年の最初の2ヶ月で京都で8万2千人の死者が出たと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that 82,000 lost their lives to famine and plague in the first two months of Year 1461 alone.
It is said that 82,000 lost their lives to famine and plague in the first two months of 1461 alone.
It is said that 82,000 lost their lives to famine and plague in Kyoto in the first two months of 1461 alone.

sen.j: だが、室町幕府の征夷大将軍足利義政はこの最中に花の御所を改築し、世事に全く関心を示さず、堪りかねた後花園天皇の勧告をも無視した。
sen.e: However, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the seii taishogun of the Muromachi bakufu, had no interest in the real world, renovated the Hana-no-gosho residence, and ignored the advice from the Emperor Gohanazono who became concered with the situation.

sen.e: The turmoil led to the beginning of the Onin war five years later.

sen.j: 延暦寺の支配下に置かれて浄土真宗の活動を禁じられていた本願寺では蓮如が救済活動の傍ら延暦寺からの独立を図ってその怒りを招き、いわゆる寛正の法難の原因となった。
sen.e: At the Hongan-ji Temple that was put under control of the Enryaku-ji Temple and was prohibited to conduct any Jodo Shinshu Sect-related activities, Rennyo tried to regain the temple's independence from the Enryaku-ji Temple while engaging himself in the rescue efforts, and met with their anger, triggering the so-called religious persecution in the Kansei Era.
